bestBHT.bht: Rejecting the Savior amidst a blaze of light will result in a judgment more severe than the punishment endured by the wicked cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. The doom of those otherwise correct individuals who reject the Savior will be less tolerable than any other. This comparison emphasizes the urgency of accepting the Gospel and highlights the grave consequences of refusing the truth, making it clear that the judgment to come will be far worse for those who reject the Savior.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Sodom sank through its vile pollutions: but the doom of otherwise correct persons who, amidst a blaze of light, reject the Saviour, shall be less endurable than that of any of these.
The doom of otherwise correct persons who, amidst a blaze of light, reject the Saviour, shall be less endurable than that of any of these.
The doom of otherwise correct persons who reject the Saviour shall be less endurable than that of any other.
Archibald T. Robertson: More tolerable (ανεκτοτερον). Comparative of the verbal adjective ανεκτος from ανεχομα. An old adjective, but only the comparative in the N.T. and in this phrase (Matthew 10:15; Matthew 11:22; Matthew 11:24; Luke 10:12; Luke 10:14).
John Gill: By 'that day' is meant, the famous day to come, the last day; the day of judgment

Though the iniquities of Sodom and Gomorrha were very great, and their punishment very exemplary; yet, as there will be degrees of torment in hell, the case of such a city, which has been favoured with the Gospel, and has despised and rejected it, will be much worse than the case of those cities, which were devoured by fire from heaven.
The case of such a city... will be much worse than... that of the inhabitants of them in the future judgment, and to all eternity.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse emphasizes that the judgment faced by those who reject the Savior despite being surrounded by the light of His truth will be more severe than that of even the notoriously wicked cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. Their doom will be less tolerable and more unbearable. The phrase more tolerable compares the punishment of the cities to the punishment awaited by those who reject Christ. This highlights the severity of the judgment to come, emphasizing the need for repentance and acceptance of the Savior's grace.

The judgment faced by those who reject the Savior amidst the light of truth will be more severe than that of even the notoriously wicked cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. Their doom will be less endurable and more unbearable, emphasizing the need for repentance and acceptance of the Savior's grace. This highlights the severity of the punishment to come and the distinction between those who reject the Gospel and those who do not. The future judgment will be much worse for those who reject the Savior, both in this life and for eternity.

The judgment faced by those who reject the Savior amidst the blazing light of truth will be more severe than even the punishment endured by the wicked cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. Their doom will be less tolerable, emphasizing the urgency of repentance and acceptance of the Savior's grace. The phrase more tolerable highlights the severity of the impending judgment for those who reject Christ, contrasting their fate with that of the inhabitants of Sodom and Gomorrah. This serves as a warning of the greater consequences for rejecting the Gospel.

Rejecting the Savior amidst a blaze of light will result in a judgment more severe than the punishment endured by the wicked cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. The doom of those otherwise correct individuals who reject the Savior will be less tolerable than any other. This comparison emphasizes the urgency of accepting the Gospel and highlights the grave consequences of refusing the truth, making it clear that the judgment to come will be far worse for those who reject the Savior.

The doom faced by those who reject the Savior amid a blaze of light will be less endurable than the punishment suffered by the wicked cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. The severity of their judgment will surpass that of any other, underscoring the consequences of rejecting the Gospel in the face of clear teachings. This serves as a stern reminder that the impending day of judgment will bring worse torment for those who reject the Savior, lasting for all of eternity.
